loans.name: Atweta Evas

texts.en:
They say that hard work pays, and a very determined Atweta Evas N. has gained from the fruits of her hard work having started up her hotel (restaurant) enterprise six years ago in Ibanda. So far, she has no regrets.

Due to Evas’ good management, esteemed customer care, and the fact that she also maintains high levels of hygiene, the business has maintained customers for a long time, thus creating a good market for her hotel.

With this loan, Evas wants to put in place good furniture and also buy foodstuffs for the hotel. This will enable her to earn more profit and be able to cater for herself and for her family and children’s requirements; she is very optimistic of achieving a self-sustaining life.

With buying in bulk, the prices are somewhat reduced and this works to Evas' advantage.

loans.use: To buy more furniture and foodstuffs for her hotel

loans.name: Kisa

texts.en: Kisa M. is a married small business woman.  She runs a business selling cosmetics to her customers. She runs a shop at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from Kariakoo city shopping center wholesale and retail shops. She purchases and sells a variety of cosmetics. The incomes generated from the business enables her to meet her family's daily demands and to expand the business. She is in need of a loan of Tshs 1,500,000 to buy more business goods to meet the customers' demands.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Jovielyn

texts.en:
Jovielyn U. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 31 years old, married and has a child aged five. She raises pigs for fattening and sale. She also has some chickens. Aside from that, she manages a sari-sari store where she sells food and basic daily necessities. She is a hard-working mother aiming to save for her child's future.

In January 2010, Jovielyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovielyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jovielyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jovielyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is married with five children.  All of her children go to school. She also takes care of her elderly mother.  She owns a stall selling secondhand clothes in Wandegeya, a neighborhood within the city of Kampala, Uganda's capital. She sells to all types of people, both retail and wholesale. Teddy buys secondhand clothes from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.  She goes shopping once a week.

Teddy wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothes.  She has been in this business for fifteen years. Besides this clothing business, she also gets additional income from rental rooms.  Teddy works seven days a week, and her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to go directly into importing these clothes.

Teddy decided to work with MCDT because they work with women who are in groups. Teddy resides in and owns a two-room house, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include paying utility bills and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: 04.01.03 - Hoang Truong - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Tam L. T. is a 28 year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Truong - Hoang Hoa .  She is the group leader of a five member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Tam is married and has three young children.  To making a living, Tam operates a fishing business.  WhiL. not her only means to generate revenue, her main source of income comes from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish to residents in the local community.  Tam has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 1500000 VND a month.

Tam joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tam is requesting her first loan of 3079800 VND to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets.  Tam plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  L. T. Thuy is a 20 year-old woman who is requesting a 3079800 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.

2.  N. T. Duyen is a 45 year-old woman who is requesting a 3079800 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.

3.  N. T. Thu is a 52 year-old woman who is requesting a 3079800 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.

4.  L. T. Huong is a 21 year-old woman who is requesting a 3079800 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.

-------------------------------------------------------------
About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.



Tam L. T. (57) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Truong - Hoang Hoa .  Tam là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 04.01.03-Hoang Truong-Hoang hoa (04.01.03-Hoang Truong-Hoang hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ thu hoạch & bán các loại cá đánh bắt ở biển trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Tam thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tam kiếm được khoảng 1,500,000 VND.  Vào 1, Tam đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tam đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,079,800 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Thuy (58) là 20 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


2.  N. T. Duyen (59) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  N. T. Thu (60) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


4.  L. T. Huong (61) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.

loans.name: Nurgul's Group

texts.en:
Today the variety of jobs and occupations has made the job market extremely wide and every individual can get occupied with any work or activity according to his own scope of interest, skills, whims and desires. The most important thing is not to slack off and be lazy. For hardworking, ambitious people there are lots of opportunities waiting for them. One has to just see it and grab it outright. This is the distinguishing trait of a successful individual: to see the chance and do his best to use it. And chances and opportunities are always there. Nurgul A. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and has three children. Her husband is a builder. To make a living, Nurgul also works.  She is a saleswoman. She trades in meat. She started working after her husband had gone to Russia to work. She needed money and instead of asking her relatives for help, decided to try being a seller and it did work out. Now, her work allows her to not only meet her family’s daily needs but also pay for her daughter’s education. Nurgul has applied for this loan to buy five sheep for feeding and resale. 

Nurgul’s partners: 

Mirlan T., 23, is single. He has decided to start his own business breeding cattle. He hopes to obtain this loan to buy cattle. Mirlan plans to do this business together with his wife.

Nargiza A., 24, is single. She trades in vegetables and fruits. Nargiza has decided to apply for this loan as she has long been planning to buy a new fridge and also to invest part of this loan in her business.

Nurlanbek T., 33, is a father of two children. His wife works as a cook. As to Nurlanbek, he is engaged in raising cattle. Nurlanbek needs this loan to pay for sowing and tractor services. 

Aida A., 31, has two children and works as a saleswoman. Her husband is a builder. Aida hopes to obtain this loan to buy four sheep. She plans to feed and resell them afterwards. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina H. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 41 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She grows hogs to fatten and sell. She also manages a farm where she plants rice. The farm and hogs have been her family's source of income for more than 12 years now. 

Merlina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Merlina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed, vitamins and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Merlina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed, vitamins and other supplies

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma Y. is from the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old. Alma is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Alma is just starting this business, Before, Alma was engaged in a sari sari store business.

In 2009, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Alma is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Alma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Normelita

texts.en:
Normelita A., 43, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has a 16-year-old child. To make a living, Normelita owns and operates a farming business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Normelita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years.

Normelita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities, and she has already successfully repaid her first loan from CEVI. Now, Normelita is requesting a second loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Gulziya's Group

texts.en: The lives of ordinary people seem to be as ordinary as the appearances of those people. However, we are not able to see the daily struggle of these people to earn their daily bread. Behind their usual expressions is hidden spiritual strength – determination to survive and achieve success in life. The heroes of our story are ordinary people but, given their mindsets and views, these people deserve special consideration. Gulziya U. is the leader of this group. She is 57 and has raised four children. Her husband works as a school teacher. Gulziya is also a school teacher but, besides that, she works in cattle breeding. Gulziya has long experience in raising cattle (12 years) and therefore does not have any difficulties in combining the two jobs. On the contrary, she is eager to work even harder as there are many things to be done. Gulziya always strives to improve her family’s living conditions. As soon as they obtained a piece of land from the state, she did not think twice and quickly started keeping cattle. After fattening the cattle, she is reselling them and buying more. Now her joint monthly income comes to around $211. Considering her initial investment of $45, she is doing pretty well! Gulziya hopes to obtain this loan to purchase fuel and sugar for making jam. Gulziya has many plans for the future. Very soon, she is going to make a grand repair of her house. Gulziya's partners: Saltanat A., 31, has two children. Her husband is occupied with farming and Saltanat sells vegetables and fruits. She needs a loan to pay for hay-cutting and tractor services. Munara J., 44, is the mother of three children. Her husband is a farmer. Munara works as a school teacher and is also engaged in farming. Munara needs this loan to purchase cattle for breeding. Mira B., 34, has two children. Together with her husband, she works at a gas station as an operator. Mira has applied for this loan to buy metal roofing for her house. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and sugar for making jam

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita D. is from the village of  Naawan Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a specialized retail store, generating revenue primarily from the sale of seafood products, including fish and shrimp. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. By now, she has already successfully repaid her first loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which she used for purchasing additional products for sale. Lolita is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of additional products for sale

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma O., 29, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has a 3-year-old child. To make a living, Alma owns and operates a farming business, with most of her revenue coming from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years. She is saving money she earns to be able to pay for her child's future education.

Alma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has already successfully repaid her first two loans  from CEVI and is now requesting a new one - in the amount of 8,000 PHP - which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Alma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: Purchase of general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Kakuuto Twetunguure Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Robert is very hardworking and ambitious towards owning a big agricultural farm in his home area of Kakuuto, Ibanda. He is in very narrow circumstances that may make him seem like a wishful thinker. This means he faces long odds in achieving that mission.

Robert has, however, built at length a strong attribute of determination that has played into his hands. With strong hardworking skills up his sleeve, he has gotten a dependable niche for his banana business. He has banked on this business for the last ten years. His family of ten children has also enjoyed the good graces that have come with doing that business. Monthly profits to the tune of 240,000 Ugandan shillings is what he has been getting of late.

With this loan, Robert hopes to purchase mulches and fertilizers to help improve his farm and also buy pesticides as pests like banana weevils have always affected the plantation, hence reducing his yields. This loan will improve his yields, hence his sales revenue, and he will be able to live a more satisfying life.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and mulches for his farm

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda A. is from the village of Naawan Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda recently started her own business venture in the retail sector, generating most of her revenue from the sale of seafood products, including fish and shrimp.

In 2009, Imelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to purchase additional products for sale. Imelda is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Purchase of additional products for sale

loans.name: 03.06.07- Hoang Thanh- Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en: Mai P. T. (101) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa. Mai is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 03.06.07- Hoang Thanh- Hoang Hoa. Mai is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mai operates a family member's business venture of raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. Mai has been engaged in this business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 1000000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from it. In 2005, Mai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She is now requesting a new loan of 5000000 VND, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fifth loan she has received from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. L. T. Huyen (97) is a 49-year-old female who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock. 2. N. T. Ninh (96) is a 37-year-old female who is also requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma P., 31 years old, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. Alma is a hard-working mother, spending most of the daytime tilling her land, preparing it for planting rice crops, and then selling the harvest to people in her community. As a result of her hard work, Alma is able to feed her family and pay for her children's education, hoping one day to see them obtain a college degree. 

Alma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
From the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province, Miriam B. is 41 years old, married, and has one school-aged child . To make a living, Miriam owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Miriam joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to invest in expanding the business, she is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Miriam plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. Based in Cagayan de Oro City, it is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Madame Khady G. est parent bénéficiaire, sociétaire  de la caisse de Ouakam depuis 7 ans. Elle a déjà rembourse 6 prêts  antérieurs. Elle évolue depuis 10 ans dans le commerce de Thiouraye, gâteau (elle a fait la pâtisserie), crème  glacée, et jus. C’est le souci d’aider son mari a supporter les charges familiales qui l’a incite a choisir cette activité. Elle a démarré  par la vente de gâteau  et de cacahuètes. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs  prévu  pour l’achat d’une plus grande quantité  de produits qu’elle commercialise pour éviter  les ruptures.
texts.en:
Khady G. has been a parent member of the Ouakam credit institution for seven years. She already repaid six previous loans. She has been running her business for over ten years; she sells thiouraye (traditional body essence), cakes that she bakes herself, ice cream and juices. She would like to help her husband with the family expenses; for this reason she started this business and she began by selling cakes and peanuts. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs in order to purchase a larger quantity of products and avoid market disruptions.

Translated from French by Monica Urban, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase stock

loans.name: Nadeem

texts.en:
Nadeem Q. is a father of two sons and one daughter. Nadeem tried many jobs, but he didn't succeed in keeping any due to the hard conditions in Palestine, in addition to the economic crisis.

Nadeem decided to start his own business and guarantee a stable income for his family. He started a small restaurant that sells traditional Palestinian meals. The restaurant is prospering, so Nadeem decided to buy a refrigerator so he could to start preparing extra meals in response to his increasing demand.

Nadeem is planning to rent a better place for his restaurant than the one appears in the picture above, where he stands. By using his business returns, he thinks he can start saving in the near future.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Arnold

texts.en:
Arnold C. Jr. is a 22-year-old, single man from the village of Port Area Iligan City. To earn a living, Arnold owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. More specifically, his primary source of business income is derived from providing computer services (games and internet acces) to local community members. Arnold has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Arnold joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, he was able to to engage in business activities and to thereby improve his standard of living. Notably, Arnold has already successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide his services. Arnold is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 8,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide his services. This loan would be the second loan taken out by Arnold from HSPFI. He plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and its mission is to reach out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To improve and expand his business by purchasing additional materials

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy L. is a 40-year-old married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She has an 11-year-old child, who is currently in school.

To earn a living, Amy works in the farming industry. Specifically, she plants and harvests rice crops, and she has been doing this for more than thirteen years now. Amy explains that loans through CEVI have immensely helped her improve her business. At present, she needs seeds, fertilizers, and other farming tools, which is why she is applying for another loan from CEVI. Indeed, she is now requesting a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($350). She also hopes to buy a piglet, which she could feed and ultimately re-sell, to general additional income.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional seeds, fertilizers, and other farming necessities

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar M. is a 46-year-old married woman from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. Maricar and her husband have 3 school-age children. To earn a living, Maricar owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, her primary source of income is derived from selling fish in her local community. Maricar has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Maricar joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Maricar has already successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to expand her business. Maricar is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 11,000 PHP ($250), which will be used to purchase more fish to re-sell for profits. Notably, this loan would be the third loan taken out by Maricar from HSPFI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and it mission is to reach out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional fish

loans.name: Help The Poor Group

texts.en:
Bawah G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Help the Poor.  She is 40 years old, married and has four children who range from 5 to 20 years old.  Bawah was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to a lack of financial support. 

For four years, Bawah has been selling tomatoes, oil, rice, onions and pepper in the Plumkor community, Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with 500 LRD and now has 9,000 LRD in working capital!

She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian dollars portion of this 42,000 Liberian dollars group loan to buy more tomatoes, rice, oil, pepper and onions.  She describes herself as an honest person.

Her goal is to improve her business to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: Buy more tomatoes, rice, gallons of oil, more pepper and onions.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn B. is a 31-year-old married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa. She and her husband have a 7-year-old child. To earn a living, she and her husband are engaged in the farming business, and they have been doing so for eight years now. Specifically, they plant rice crops. While her husband performs the primary farming duties, she is the one who sells their harvest at the market. She also makes sure that her family is healthy and happy, and she saves for her child's education.

In 2005, Analyn joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby help improve her standard of living. Analyn is now requesting a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($350), which would be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Notably, this loan would be the eighth loan taken out by Analyn from CEVI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from their business as a result of the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About CEVI: CEVI has increased its portfolio significantly over the past few years. Based in Bohol, CEVI has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, all of which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad Amro is an ambitious young man from Ramallah. He owns a gift and accessories store, where he stands in the picture above. His store is located in front of Al-Quds Open University of Ramallah. Ahmad is originally from Hebron. He moved to Ramallah to find a better job and ended up having this store. 

Ahmad had always passion for books. Because his shop is in front of the university, he wanted to have a specialized books section in his store, and since he is financially tied, he came to FATEN and took a $3,000 loan for this purpose.

Ahmad is trying to have a variety of useful books to respond to all interests of university students. The new book section will fulfill his ambitions of having books in his store and will improve his financial situation.

loans.use: Prepare a bookstore

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia B. is a 39-year-old married woman. Her husband is a policeman. She and her husband have four children, all of whom are in school. To earn a living, Julia is in the business of selling green vegetables at the market. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $350 to stock fish to sell at the market to generate additional income. With the expected extra profits as a result of the loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop of her own.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. All of these services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To expand her business operations by purchasing fish

loans.name: Look Up To God Group

texts.en:
Rita Q., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Look Up To God.  She is 30 years old, married and has one child who is 11 years old. 

She was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For five years, she has been selling beans, oil, pepper, and peanuts at the Old Road Market, outside Monrovia, Liberia. 

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollars group loan to buy more beans, oil, pepper, and peanuts.  She describes herself as a hard working and faithful person.

Her plan is to grow her business, build a house and continue to support her child so that he can have a better future.

loans.use: Buy more beans, oil, pepper, and peanuts.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy S. is currently in the business of selling carrots and irish potatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and rice to sell.  Judy is 41 years old and is widowed.   She has 6 children and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Ndeye Bineta

texts.fr: Madame Ndeye  Bineta B.  habite dans la localité de Ouakam. Elle est âgée de 30 ans. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse depuis 2 ans et a déjà  bénéficié  de 2 prêts  antérieurs. Elle est mariée, mère de 3 enfants et s’active depuis 7 ans dans la vente de petit déjeuner  et d’amuse gueule. Elle a choisi cette activité  pour éviter  le chômage. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 100 000 frs dans le but de développer  son commerce et satisfaire sa clientèle  qui augmente de jour en jour( sur la photo on peut constater  des clients qui attendent d'etre servis). Le prêt qui lui sera octroyé  pourra lui permettre d’accroitre ses bénéfices  et d’assurer une meilleure prise en charge des besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ndeye Bineta B. lives in the locality of Ouakam. She is 30-years old. She has been a member of the credit institution for two years and has previously been granted two loans. She is married with three children and for the past seven years, she has been selling breakfast and finger food. She chose this activity to avoid unemployment. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 francs to expand her business and satisfy her customers whose number is increasing every day (the photo shows customers waiting to be served). The loan will enable her to boost her profits and better provide for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase funding

loans.name: Franchis

texts.en:
Franchis A. is currently in the business of selling juice such as: mango juice, ice cream, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more ingredients to make juice to sell.  Franchis is 20 years old and is single.   With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a fridge for keeping her juice cool.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more ingredients to make juice to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel runs Tavsi General Shop where he earns his income.  He has been in business for five years and is happy because of his improved living standards.  Emmanuel joined a group called Minds Together and as the name suggests, the group members share business ideas.  They also guarantee each other's loans, therefore he can easily get a loan from Faulu Kenya.  He previously serviced two loans through the group. This has helped him invest in his business, hence raising his living standards.  He has requested for a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to add stocks of sugar, cooking fat, soaps and sweets.  He hopes to open a supermarket in the near future.

loans.use: To add stock of sugar, cooking fat,detergents and sweets

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane W. is currently in the business of selling fresh fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions and cooking oil to sell.  Jane is 38 years old and is widowed.   She has 2 children who both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to rent a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Mareme

texts.fr: Madame Mareme S. est une ancienne sociétaire  de la caisse de Ouakam. Elle est membre depuis 9 ans et a déjà  solde 5 crédits  antérieurs. Elle est âgée  de 41 ans. Elle est parent bénéficiaire, mariée  et mère  de 3 enfants. Elle évolue  depuis plus de 5 ans dans le commerce de produits cosmétiques  et la coiffure (tresse). C’est dans le souci d’aider son mari à supporter les charges de la famille qu’elle s’est lancée  dans ces activités. Ainsi elle sollicite un crédit  de 100 000 frs qui sera destine a l’achat de produits cosmétiques   afin de développer d’avantage son commerce.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mareme S. is a long-time member of the Ouakam credit branch. She has been a member for nine years and has fully repaid five previous loans. She is 41-years old. She is a recipient parent, married with three children. She has been active in the business of selling cosmetics and styling hair (braids) for over five years. She started this activity to help her husband provide for the needs of their family. She is seeking a loan of 100 000 francs to purchase cosmetic products in order to expand her business.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase funding

loans.name: God’S Gift Group

texts.en:
Yah G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God’s Gift. She is 36 years old, married and has four children who range from 20 to 8 years old. 

She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For 10 years, she has been selling beans, oil, pepper, and peanuts slippers, soft drinks, water and biscuits in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. She cares for one sibling.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more slippers, soft drinks, water and biscuits. She describes herself as respectful and hardworking.

Her dream is to grow her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: Buy more slippers, soft drinks, water and biscuits.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice Y. is currently in the business of selling dresses and bedsheets at the shop and is requesting a loan to stock pairs of trousers and shoes to sell.  Joice is 39 years old and is married with a husband that is a teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bakery.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock pairs of trousers and shoes to sell

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi W. T. is 40 years old, and she is a member of the Super Njunu group in Faulu Kenya. Naomi is married, and her husband is also a businessman. They have six children, all of whom go to school. Together with her husband, they work hard to educate her children. To earn a living, she sells fruits and vegetables. She is well-known for her participation in the group because she consistently attends their weekly meetings. She also promptly pays her weekly dues.

She is now seeking a loan in the amount of 50,000 KES ($625) to buy more fruits and vegetables. She believes that she will generate additional profits if she could increase her stock.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Pendo Group

texts.fr:
Patricie N. est une commerçante âgée de 47ans qui habite la Commune de Rugombo en Province Cibitoke  à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de patates douces depuis trois ans au Marche de Rugombo.Elle était cultivatrice avant de commencer cette activité commerciale. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 4e année du primaire. Elle est  une veuve. Elle est maintenant  au 4e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 3 garçons dont 2 sont à l’école. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour augmenter  la quantité de patates douces qu’elle achète pour revendre aux clients . Elle a l’espoir qu’avec le crédit de Turame, elle pourra avoir beaucoup de bénéfice et faire ses épargnes pour résoudre ses divers problèmes financiers et s’acheter sa propre maison.
Elle reconnait que Turame lui est venu en aide au bon moment parce que elle travaillait pour les autres afin d’avoir de quoi manger mais maintenant le crédit de Turame a amélioré son mode de vie

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Pendo ».
texts.en:
Patricie N. is a 47 year old merchant. She lives in the town of Rugombo in the Cibitoke province in the western part of Burundi. She has been selling sweet potatoes for three years at the Rugombo market. Before starting this business, she was a farmer. She studied until the 4th year of primary school. She is a widow. She is currently in the 4th cycle of the community loan with Turame. She is the mother of 3 boys of which 2 go to school. She is requesting a Kiva loan to increase the quantity of sweet potatoes that she buys to resell to her customers. With the loan from Turame, she hopes to increase her profits and save money to solve her various financial problems and buy her own house. She acknowledges that Turame helped her at the right moment, as she worked for others in order to be able to have enough to eat. Her way of living has now improved thanks to the Turame loan. She is one of the members of the « Pendo » community group.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the quantity of sweet potatoes that she buys to resell to her customers

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian F. is a 31-year-old married woman. To earn a living, her husband works as a driver. She and her husband have 2 children, one of whom is in school. At present, she is in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $175 to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant. With the expected additional profits generated by the business as a result of the loan, she would like to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. All of these services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To improve and expand her restaurant business by purchasing additional food

loans.name: Asiaha

texts.en:
Asiaha B. is a 32-year-old married woman. To earn a living, her husband is a teacher. She and her husband have 3 children, two of whom are in school. Asiaha is currently in the business of selling bags of groundnuts and maize flour at the market. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $175 to stock more nuts to sell. With the expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan, she hopes to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. All of these services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is a father of four who lives with his wife and children in Machakos.  He operates a Mutongoni cafeteria to provide for his family.  His wife assists him to run the business along with two other employees.   Bernard has the skills to run a cafeteria because he was previously employed in a hotel. He also operates a taxi business to supplement his family’s income.  

Bernard, who has been running his cafeteria for twenty five years, joined a group called Ushindi Thiliu in Faulu, Kenya.  He saves his money with the group on a weekly basis.  He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to buy wheat flour, sugar and cooking fat as ingredients for cooking.  He hopes to buy another car for his taxi business to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, sugar and cooking fat as ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Myriam

texts.en:
Myriam was born in 1968 and is married with three children. Myriam's husband is on the governor's staff. This couple works hard in order to develop their family by providing all basic needs for their children. Myriam sells various products in her shop as you find them in the picture. She has an experience of two years in this field and her business starts 7 in the morning and is open to 8 in the evening every day.

Myriam is now requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business. The expansion expected by Myriam will help her to save money which will allow Myriam to renovate her house.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian C. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil to sell.  Lilian is 19 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock cooking oil to sell

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Glorious J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. She is 29 years old, married and has two children who range from 6 to 14 years old. 

She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to lack of financial support. She cares for one sibling.

For four years, she has been operating a beauty salon in the Old Road Market, outside Monrovia, Liberia. 

She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 32,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more hair product such as gel, shampoo, sheen oil etc. She describes herself as a respectful person.

Her dream is to grow her business and travel abroad to do international business.

loans.use: Buy more hair product such as gel, shampoo, sheen oil etc.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en: Kenneth operates a cafeteria where he employs two people.  As a business man, he joined a group called Ngegu Small Traders in Faulu, Kenya to access financial resources.  He is able to save his money with the group members on weekly basis.  He has been guaranteed a loan of 40,000 KES by the group members.  With the loan, he wants to buy ingredients for cooking.  He hopes to buy a piece of land and build rental houses in the future.  Kenneth is a married man with two children.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras Group

texts.es:
El comité “Las Triunfadoras” se encuentra dentro del 6to. Ciclo del Programa de Comités de Mujeres en la ciudad de Roque Alonso. 
Cada una de las integrantes trabajan en actividades diferentes, pero además se reúnen constantemente para realizar algunas actividades en grupo.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Nancy  quien se dedica a la reposteria elaborando tortas para fiesta infantiles, quince años, bodas y otros.
Ella estudio un buen tiempo para adquirir la profesión de repostera.
Ella trabaja de acuerdo a los pedidos que recibe de sus clientes, los fines de semana con mucho mas auge que los otros días, puede llegar a tener 3 a 4 pedidos de tortas los fines de semana. 
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de una batidora ya que le será muy util en su trabajo, ademas desea comprar algunos ingredientes para reposteria como harinas especiales, azucar, colorantes y otros.
texts.en:
The “Las Triunfadoras” ("The Winners") Group is in its sixth cycle of the Women's Group Program in the city of Roque Alonso. Each of the members works in a different activity, but they get together regularly to complete various activities as a group. One of the group's members is Ms. Nancy, who works as a confectioner. She makes cakes for children's parties, quinceañeras, weddings, and other events. Nancy studied for a good amount of time in order to become a pastry baker. She works according to the orders she receives from her customers, with the weekends much busier than other days. She can receive 3 or 4 cake orders for a weekend. She is requesting this loan to purchase an electric mixer, as it would be very useful in her work. She would also like to buy certain ingredients for her cakes, such as special flours, sugar, food coloring, and other ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric mixer, sugar, flour, food coloring, and other ingredients for baking cakes

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace M. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Grace is 41 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor bike to transport charcoal. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Badenya sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames.  Elles ont un âge moyen de 33 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le chef lieu de commune rurale: Cinzana Gare dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage dans le village. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente des foulards, des boissons locales (le Dolo à base de mil), des condiments alimentaires (piments, ail et échalotes) et des ustensiles en plastiques (seaux et tasses). 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont  décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Mariam K. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 douzaines de seaux et 3 douzaines de tasses en plastiques. 
Elle se ravitaille en ustensiles en plastiques à Koutiala en gros et effectue sa vente au comptant ou à crédit à la foire du village et à domicile à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame Mariam K.  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et acheter petit à petit des petits ruminants pour des fins d’élevage.
texts.en:
The four members of the Badenya group are married women who mostly live in monogamous households. They are all around 33 years old with three children. They all live in the main area of their rural living place: in Cinzana Gare in the Ségou region (the fourth largest administrative region of Mali), and met through neighbours, family and friends in the village. The members of the group buy and sell foulards, local drinks (Dolo, a millet-based drink), condiments (spices, garlic and shallots) and plastic utensils (buckets and cups). In order to increase their business funds, the members of the group have decided to seek help from the Soro Yiriwaso credit association and are on their third loan. Madame Mariam K. aims to use her loan to buy 5 dozen buckets and 3 dozen plastic cups; she sources her plastic utensils in bulk at Koutiala and takes cash or credit sales in local markets and at home; her customer base is made up of women and men. She hopes to generate an average monthly profit of 27 000 FCFA which will be reinvested into her business, and also used to buy animals to rear.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase plastic utensils (buckets and cups)

loans.name: Lokina Enole

texts.en:
Lokina Enole S. is 44 years old and is married to David Sadera. They have two children who both go to school.

Lokina is a farmer who later sells what she harvests at a profit. She has been doing this for the last ten years.

She learned about KADET from another womens group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her first loan which she is planning to spend on preparing her land for wheat planting. Wheat has been doing well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Lokina's dream is do large scale farming and attain financial independence. She describes herself as a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To plough her two acres of land for wheat planting.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria Agoyong is a 45-year old widow who supports her family by operating a food vending business.  She lives in Prk. Masinadyahon, Brgy. Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard she has gradually made her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP5,500. 

Maria is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so she can buy more items for her food vending business.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon.  Her previous loan of PHP10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Maria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

---------------------------------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Aliou

texts.fr: Monsieur Aliou S. est un commerçant  qui exerce l’activité  de vente de tissus depuis plus de 10 ans. Il est âgé  de 42 ans, marie et père  de 2 enfants. Il est membre de l’U-IMCEC depuis mars 2006. Il a choisi son activité  par expérience. Il sollicite un crédit  de 250 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat de tissu s destines à accroitre son stock pour atteindre son objectif qui est de satisfaire   la demande de sa clientèle. L’accroissement  de ses bénéfices  à travers ce financement pourra lui permettre d’atteindre une certaine autonomie financière  et par conséquent  d’améliorer  les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Aliou S. is an entrepreneur who has been selling fabrics for over ten years. He is 42 years old, married and the father of two children. He has been a member of U-IMCEC since March 2006. He has chosen this line of business because he was familiar with it. He is seeking a loan of 250,000 West African francs in order to increase his stock of fabrics, with the goal of satisfying his customers’ needs. Increasing his income thanks to this loan could allow him to reach a certain financial independence and thus improve the life conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing his working capital

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is aged 46 years, married, and has four children.  She deals in the sale of household products and conducts her business in a shopping centre near Nairobi town. Her clients are mainly mid-level income earners from the banana plantations. She has been in the same business for the past months. 

Lilian has applied for a loan which she intends to use to add more stock of household products and thus also increase the range of products. In future she intends to build a modern house after expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase stock of plastic containers, cooking pans and household utensils

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo P. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Mabinuligon, Brgy. Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and standing cane businesses.  Her husband Crispin, who is 74 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and he also helps his wife.  They have seven children who are 28 to 50 years old. 

Amparo joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Amparo has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000.  

This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000 to buy standing cane and stocks for her general store so that she could continue to save up for future home repairs and to expand her standing cane business.  Amparo is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

---------------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Siporah Gitura

texts.en:
Siporah Gitura K. is 53 years old. She is married to John K. and a mother of two school-going children. Siporah is a farmer and she does the farming on her own piece of land which she has been doing for the last seven years.

She learned about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET. This will be her first loan which she is planning to spend to prepare land for potato planting. Potatoes have been doing well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Siporah's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. She is a hard-working woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To spend 25,000 on harrowing, 20,000 on seeds and fertilizer and 15,000 on planting

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena D. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Mabinuligon, Brgy. DSB, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and pig fattening business. Her husband Federico D., who is 48 years old, works as a carpenter and farmer to earn his living.  He also helps in his wife.  They have four children who are 17 to  21 years old. 

Ma. Elena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past seven cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Elena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty.

This time, for her 8th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500 to buy piglets and for additional capital so she can continue to save up for the future education of children.  Ma. Elena D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

---------------------------

loans.name: Linjina

texts.en:
Linjina E. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions to sell.  Linjina is 33 years old and is married to a husband who is a security guard. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions to sell

loans.name: Longisa Ole

texts.en:
Longisa Ole K. is 50 years old. He is married to Sereya K. and a father of two school-going children. Longisa is a farmer and he has been doing farming for the last ten years and later selling his produce at a profit.

He learned about KADET from a friend who is a registered client of KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend to prepare land for wheat planting. Wheat has been doing well in his area due to good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Longisa's dream is do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To spend 20,000 KES on ploughing, 10,000 on harrowing, 10,000 on seeds and fertlizer, and 10,000 on planting

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick is a 35-year-old farmer.  He has two children in school.  He has been practicing dairy farming for nine years together with Ikinu Aimers group members in Faulu Kenya.  In this group, the members guarantee each other's loans.  Therefore, he has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to renovate his zero-grazing unit and buy animal feed.  Fredrick who also keeps poultry hopes to improve his living standard and educate his children to university level.

loans.use: To renovate his zero-grazing unit and buy animal feed

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline A. is a 53-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing business.  She lives in Purok 3, Brgy. Linaon, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of PHP20,000. 

Evangeline is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so she can build a new pump boat.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Evangeline aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

--------------------------------------------------

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her neighborhood store

loans.name: Dembe Mixed Group, Mityana

texts.en:
N. Sylivia is not part of the group photo but her small photo appears in the top left corner of the main picture and she is the person that was interviewed.

N. Sylivia, a 35-year-old happily married mother of three, has been plying her retail shop business for the last four years in Wabigalo, Mityana. In a cutthroat competitive business like retail, one needs to conjure up ways and means and also one needs to strike a profound first impression with customers to get a niche in the market. Sylvia has used her good customer care skills as her business stock-in-trade.

Long before Sylivia drew up plans of establishing this business, she was more inclined to a commercial agricultural business. In the course of time, she wanted to emulate the successful businesswomen her village had produced. After second thought, she embarked on her business four years ago with a sense of determination that is essential at the threshold of any business.

In a month, Sylvia reckons she makes profits that total up to 350,000 shillings. Her husband, too, has been part of her success story as he is invariably at her beck and call in her operations. Sylvia also supplements her retail profits with the earnings from her agricultural business, which was originally her first business.

With this loan, Sylivia is intent on purchasing in bulk more retail items like beans, rice, sugar and soap which she will later resell.

loans.use: To purchase more retail goods like sugar, soap, rice, etc.

loans.name: Joyce Naisiae

texts.en:
Joyce Naisiae L. is 54 years old. She is married to Francis L. and a mother of four children. Joyce is a farmer and she does poultry keeping which she has been doing for the last two years at her home.

She learned about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her first loan which she will use to increase the number of broilers and expand the henhouse so as to keep more hens. Poultry-keeping has been a good business for her as most of the hotels get their orders from her. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her poultry farming activity from small-scale to large-scale.

Joyce's dream is do large-scale poultry farming and attain financial independence. She is a hard-working woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To spend 20,000 KES to buy more broilers and 20,000 to construct another henhouse

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella E. is currently in the business of selling dried fish, tomatoes, and onions  at the market and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes to sell.  Stella is 39 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James N. M. is thirty one years old, married and has two children, ages five years old and four months. 

He sells clothes, shoes and handbags to local people.  His eight year old business is profitable.  But James' major challenge is that there are so many people running the same kind of business: competition.  However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well.  He will use his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more skirt suits and men's suits to sell.  He hopes to open two boutiques in the future. He describes himself as very hardworking, polite and hardworking.

loans.use: Buy skirt suits, men suits to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen B. is a 59-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing business.  She lives in Purok 2, Brgy. Linaon, Cauayan , Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1995 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of PHP10,000.  

Helen is now borrowing PHP 18,500 for the renovation of her pump boat.  This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Helen aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.
