loans.name: Perizat's Group

texts.en:
Perizat K., 29, is the leader of the group. She works as a teacher at a school. Ten years ago with the initial investment of 4500 soms, Perizat bought three farm animals and began to breed livestock. Her brother helps her with this activity and now they have increased the number of livestock to fifteen. With money received from the loan, Perizat wants to purchase three animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future she plans to purchase building materials and begin to construct a house.

Daiyrbek M., 24, is married. In 2006 with the initial investment of 10000 soms he bought six farm animals and began to breed cattle. He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase two sheep in order to increase the number of his livestock. In the future he wants to purchase a car and start building a house.

Guluipa S., 22, is married. She breeds livestock and her husband works on construction. When the husband is free, he helps her with that activity. Guluipa started to breed livestock five years ago, with the initial investment of 3000 soms. With that money she bought two goats. Guluipa wants to get a loan, because she needs 3000 soms to pay for her study at university and with 4000 soms she wants to purchase two farm animals to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to save some money and repair her house.

Gulmira S., 28, is the treasurer of the group. She has two daughters and two sons. The older daughter and the older son are at school, and the others are not yet old enough. In 2001 with the initial investment of 12000 soms, Gulmira bought twelve farm animals and began to breed livestock. Her husband works as a taxi-driver and when he is free, he helps her with that activity. Gulmira applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase six sheep.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en: Jacob K. Kisoi is 49 years old and married with 4 children ages 9-19.  He hopes to provide them with a quality education. His business is located at Maasai market in Kisumu city along the Kisumu-Nairobi highway. He has been selling curios, necklaces, bangles, and carvings to tourists for 15 years. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is lack of adequate marketing. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more carvings to sell so he can grow his business.  He hopes to open a tours and travel company in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and self motivated.

loans.use: To buy more carvings for selling.

loans.name: Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Salamat C. is the leader of the group. She is 59 and married. She and her husband are retired. In order to make some money, Salamat works in a sewing workshop and her husband provides welder services, and they also breed cattle. They have a son; he is 27 and works as a horse-breeder. When he is free, he helps his parents with cattle breeding. Salamat started to breed cattle eleven years ago; she got some cattle as an inheritance from her parents. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase two farm animals in order to sell them after fattening and make some money.

Iygilik Z., 31, is married. He works as a programmer and his wife studies at university. He applied for the loan, because he needs money to pay for his wife’s education. In the future he wants to open a kiosk and sell convenience goods.

Tolokan M., 44, is married. She works as a teacher in kindergarten and her husband works as a driver and receives 3500 soms per month. Tolokan and her husband also breed cattle; they have been doing it for fourteen years. They have a son and a daughter; the daughter studies at school and the son went to work in construction to earn some money. Tolokan wants get a loan because she needs money to pay for her daughter’s studies. In the future she wants to build a house in Bishkek.

Sveta U. is 37 and married. She works as a teacher at a school. She also breeds cattle, like most families in their village. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for the animals. In the future Sveta wants to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
K. Vincent is a hardworking and well-trained person who runs a drug shop in Ibanda. These drugs are used by his customers to treat their sicknesses, hence being in high demand. This business has been in place for a period of fifteen years and has always brought to him dividends close to 400,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

Vincent’s main drawback is having a small stock which is hindering business growth and expansion. With this loan he looks forward to do restocking his drugs. Thus, he will be in a position to earn more revenue and also be able to acquire a self-sustaining life.

The kind of drugs that Vincent needs to purchase include artemether (an antimalarial treatment), tablets, syringes, needles and so on.

Jeana has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jeana joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to  purchase additional products to sell. Jeana is requesting a second loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Virgilia Burlat Group

texts.en:
Virgilia B. is from the village of Unidos. She is 64 years-old and she is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Virgilia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Virgilia owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Virgilia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Virgilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Virgilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Virgilia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Tsendee

texts.en:
Tsendee D. is 41 years-old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvs province in western Mongolia. His three children attend a local middle school and his wife works as a typist in the local Meteorology Office. 

Tsendee operates a coal selling business in his town.  He purchases coal directly from local mines in the winter time and transports it between towns. Tsendee has operated this business since 1990 and has gained much experience over the years. He has a large customer base with many loyal clients and he plans to purchase an economical car to keep up with the growing demand. 

He also operates a meat trading business in order to further improve his quality of life. He said, “the old Russian trucks are very outdated. People with newer, larger, fuel efficient trucks have higher earnings than I. My wish is to have one of these trucks.” Tsendee is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase sheep and sell them in Darhan, the third largest city in Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to sell.

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn G. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 36 years-old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Emelyn owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 14 years. She says the reason she works hard is for her family to have nutritious food on the table and to provide for their other needs.

Emelyn joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and fertilizers. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Emelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Bat-Orshih

texts.en:
Bat-Orshih D. is 44 years-old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two younger daughters currently attend the local middle school and the oldest daughter is married and lives in her own house with her family. 

Bat-Orshih operates a wood product making business in his town. The business is very family oriented, as he designs and produces the products while his wife, Oyuntsetseg, paints and decorates them. Bat-Orshih started his wood products business in 1990 with capital of 60,000 MNT. The business has been successful and they have grown into a stable operation. Today, his working capital exceeds 1,300,000 MNT. 

Bat-Orshih attributes his success to the quality of his products which are much desired by his customers. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and paint for their wood products business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and paints.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 39 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 17 years.

Emma joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Emma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: Liza Magamay Group

texts.en:
Liza M., from the village of Upper Puntod, is the 35-year-old group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While both members receive an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if delinquency or default occurs.

Liza, who is married and has eight school-aged children, owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be Liza's fifth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Jeni

texts.en:
Jeni C. is from the village of Katipa. She is 40 years old and single. To make a living, Jeni runs a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. 

In 2006, Jeni joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to purchase additional products to sell and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jeni from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Bolor-Erdene

texts.en:
Bolor-Erdene T. is 42 years-old and lives with his wife and two sons in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional housing tent. His wife works in the local Vocational Training Center and the two sons attend the middle school in their town.

Bolor-Erdene operates a food retailing business out of a small shop. He started his business in 2004 with a working capital of 100,000 MNT and since then it has increased to 6,000,000 MNT. Over the years Bolor-Erdene has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. His wife always helps him with his business and sells the products as well. His business is very important to him and his family. He says, "My only wish is to enlarge the business and create our own food industry." Bolor-Erdene is a hardworking person. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for his business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
42-year-old Evelyn D. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has two school-aged children. She is involved in farming. She tills her land for rice crops and sells her harvest in her town's local market. She also grows hogs for fattening and sale. She plans to have all her children finish college and find appropriate jobs for themselves.

Evelyn joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and feed for the pigs. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Byambahishig

texts.en:
Byambahishig N. is 40 years-old and lives with her husband and two children in their own house in Arhangai province, central Mongolia. Her children currently attend the local middle school and her husband helps her with sales in their business.  

Byambahishig operates a food selling business out of the rented stall. When she started her business in 1996, her working capital was 3,000,000 MNT and now it has reached 4,000,000 MNT. Over the years she has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. With her business profits, she has purchased a small truck and finished the house they currently live in. Byambahishig is very hard working and dislikes to be discouraged. Her wish is to expand her business and create an expanded range of items to be sold through her own store. Byambahishig is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase more food to sell.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Kyaitamba Tweyambe Group

texts.en: Annet is a 35-year-old woman and a single mother. She heads a family of six people living in a house Annet has constructed through her own efforts. She operates a restaurant in which she sells food and drinks. She has been in the business for the last five years. Before starting her business, Annet was working for a plantation as a casual labour. She says prospects are promising and she hopes to see her business progress to the next level. Annet is a member of the group called "Kyaitamba Tweyambe". There are 10 members with two women and eight men. This is a solidarity kind of borrowing where each of the members is a guarantor to the others to ensure that they all meet their obligations on time and in equal amounts. This is the group’s first loan cycle, and Annet intends to use the loan funds to purchase wheat flour to make mandazi (a donut-like pastry) for her restaurant business. In the picture, Annet is raising her arm.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour for her restaurant to make "mandazi"

loans.name: Horolgarav

texts.en:
Horolgarav is 43 years-old and lives with her husband and 19 year-old son in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. Her son currently attends the local high school. 

Horolgarav operates a meat selling business in her town with the help of her husband. She offers a variety of locally produced meats to her customers through selling at the local market. Horlgarav started her meat business in 1996 with capital of 200,000 MNT. Her business has found success over the years and she has built a good reputation amongst her customers. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,500,000MNT. 

For the future, Horolgarav hopes that she can become a meat wholesaler and that she can sell on a larger scale. She also dreams of one day having her own meat trading shop. She is a hard working and creative woman who is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Zam

texts.en: Zam is married to a machine operator in a coffee factory. The couple has five children, all of whom go to school, and they don't take care of additional family members. Zamu owns a stall in Kawempe Mbogo selling bananas and charcoal. Zam would like to go directly to farmers in Masaka for bananas, but currently she buys bunches of bananas from delivery vans which transport them from the Masaka district in central eastern Uganda. She doesn’t pay to transport charcoal because she buys it from her place of work. Zam wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, bags of charcoal and fish. Since Zam works from home seven days a week, she doesn’t pay rent for her business. Her main challenge is the rainy season because it hinders her customers reaching her as she works in a muddy place. Zam decided to work with MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. Zam resides in and owns a three roomed house. Her family has access to electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, fish and bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Otgontenger

texts.en: Otgontenger V. is 23 years old and lives with her husband in Arhangai province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She and her husband work as drivers in their town. The couple started their transportation business in 2009. During the last year, she has saved money to improve her family's quality of life. Otgontenger is an open-minded, hard working and tidy woman. She is requesting a 650,000 MNT loan in order to buy newer, more comfortable furniture for their home.

loans.use: To purchase furniture.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily A. N. is forty years old, married and has three children to whom they hope to give a good education. Her business is located at Kibuye market in Kisumu. She has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, rice and millet for the last three years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is fluctuating market prices, which is why she sells her products at low prices. However she works very hard so her business does well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business. She hopes to have many business outlets and supply her cereals wholesale to different parts of the country in future. Emily wants to grow her business and describes herself as humble, hardworking, trustworthy and understanding.

loans.use: To purchase cereals for resale.

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Happy A., a 38-year-old divorced mother of two, is indeed, like her name suggests, a happy-go-lucky person. This is not only in her character but also stretches to her business operations.

Being a farmer, Happy knows that establishing good working relationship with clients who buy your crops is crucial. When you accord them good hospitality when transacting business with them, you are bound to reap big in terms of finances and also establishing a good business relationship. A. has been a true manifestation of that in the three years she has been running her farm.

In a week, Happy calculates her profits add up to 30,000 shillings. With hard work, her level of optimism is high that she will consolidate her business further in the future. She has relied on this rather fledgling business, being that it is only three years old, to educate all her children and also improve her family’s welfare.

With this loan, Happy is planning to purchase manure for her gardens and also pay for mulching.

loans.use: To purchase manure for her gardens and also pay for mulching

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a 38 year-old woman who sells clothing. She has been in business for 10 years and sells both men’s and women’s clothing in a busy market.  Her biggest business challenges are lots of competition and the high cost of new clothes that her customers can afford. She is married and has four children, one boy and 3 girls, aged between 10 and 18. 

Irene plans to use the 60,000 Kenya Shilling loan to purchase new clothing stock and more recent fashions. She hopes to become the leading provider of new, fashionable clothes in town. In five years, she dreams of expanding and opening a boutique to better serve her clients.

loans.use: To increase and vary her inventory

loans.name: Saijmaa

texts.en: Saijmaa T. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvs province in western Mongolia. Her youngest son attends a local middle school, while the elder two children are also students. Saijmaa and her husband make wooden furniture in their town; Saijmaa decorates the items that her husband makes. Saijmaa wants to one day own a small cattle farm where she can expand her business's operations and further improve her family’s finances. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to buy a plot of land where the family can build a small cow pen and purchase some milking cows.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land for cattle.

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en: In the small town of Karuguuza, Uganda, lives a young man called Jimmy. Jimmy, like majority of his village mates, is business oriented and sells the local brew which is known as waragi. Jimmy is 30 years old and married. He says business is good so far; only that transportation of the brew is still a challenge, as roads are bad and vehicles are scarce. He says he would like to have bigger stores so as to be a bigger supplier of the local brew. This is Jimmy’s first loan cycle and he intends to purchase local brew to sell.

loans.use: To purchase local brew to sell

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela V. is thankful for the support she got from Kiva lenders for her sari-sari (variety) store and prays that they all be blessed. Rosela is requesting a new Kiva loan of 40,000 Php for her store. She has been able to improve her business due to her access to credit through Kiva lenders. Rosela is happy that she is able to augment her husband’s income and meet the needs of her family. 

A committed member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Rosela has been a model member since 2002, demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayment of previous Kiva loans.

Rosela’s business has helped her achieve her dreams. Her greatest ambition is that her family will be able to have a decent way of life. 

Rosela and her family feel very glad about the service of KIVA lenders. It gives them a way to pursue their family dreams. Rosela hopes that they extend the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead and escape the spiral of poverty.

Her long term goals are to help support her grandchildren's education, invest, build a better house for the family, and to have a full-fledged mini-grocery store.

loans.use: To support her sari-sari (variety) store.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun S., 49 years old, is a villager who lives in Trapeang Kralanh village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Ok Horm, own a plot of land where they cultivate rice and earn a small income to support their family.

Mrs. Hun S. is asking for a loan to buy an ox to add with her older ox to support her farming chores.

The couple has five children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other three study in the local school and also help their parents with farming. Mrs. Hun S.'s husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy an ox.

loans.name: Nim

texts.en:
Mrs. Nim C., 44 years old, is a villager who lives in Trapeang Phlu village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband earns a small income through his motorcycle repair business.

In order to increase income to improve her family's living standard, Mrs. Nim C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a machine charger to support her husband's business. 

The couple has three children who are students and also help with their parents' businesses. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To purchase a machine charger.

loans.name: Berigita

texts.en:
Berigita is a 55-year-old tailor who specializes in making dresses and school uniforms. She sells clothes to women and primary school children at a small market in a residential area. One disadvantage is that it is not easy to attract new customers at her current location.

She has been in this business for ten years and has two employees. Berigita is married and has four children, two sons and two daughters. 

Berigita plans to use the 50,000 KES loan to purchase more fabric at lower prices for ladies' dresses. Buying in larger quantities allows her to avoid higher prices for rush orders. She has successfully repaid seven previous loans.

Berigita hopes to educate her children and provide a good future for them. In five years, she dreams of increasing her production, adding new items like men’s suits, and owning her own business premises in a more strategic location.

Berigita describes herself as humble, reliable, and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Clariet

texts.en:
Clariet is a 36 year-old woman who sells second-hand clothing. She sells shirts and skirts at a market near a busy highway. Unfortunately, there are many people who conduct the same kind of business, so competition is one of her biggest business challenges. Local authority regulations can also cause problems. Clariet has been in this business for 4 years.  

Clariet is married and has 2 children, a 13 year old son and an 8 year old daughter. She plans to use the 20,000 Kenya Shilling loan to purchase additional stock of clothing for resale, especially newer fashions. Clariet hopes to expand her business to become the leading provider of second-hand clothing in town. In 5 years, she dreams of moving from selling second-hand clothes to selling new clothes that she would purchase from Dubai. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of clothing for resale, especially newer fashions.

loans.name: Soth

texts.en: Mrs. Soth N. lives with family members in a commune in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Soth N. makes a living by sewing clothes in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Sophal, is a 41-year-old building constructor and earns about $5 per day. They have three children, two of whom are employed; the other one attends school. Soth N. has a problem: her house doesn’t have electricity. She hopes to connect it by requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner, HKL, in the amount of $600 to be used to pay the fee of connecting a new electricity system for family use.

loans.use: To connect a new electricity system

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret, who is married with six children, all of whom attend school, sells soda and passion juice seven days a week in Kawempe market. She buys crates of soda from delivery vans and passion fruits from Bwaise farmers' market. As well, Margaret owns rental rooms. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of soda, a bag of passion juice and 20 kilograms of sugar.

In this business for 20 years, Margaret's challenges include seasonality and thieves. She joined MCDT because of the low interest rate charged. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. Her monthly expenses include market dues, food and school fees. Margaret aspires to build more rental rooms and also to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda, a bag of passion fruits and 20 kilograms of sugar

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Severa

texts.en:
Severa L. is a 44-year-old married woman from the village of Lapasan Cagaya de Oro City. She and her husband have 4 school-age children. To earn a living, Severa owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, her primary source of income is derived from buying and selling of rice in her local community. Severa has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2004, Severa joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Recently, Severa successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 28,000 PHP from HSPFI. This prior loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Severa is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 31,000 PHP ($675), which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. Notably, this loan would be the twelfth loan taken out by Severa from HSPFI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of this loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and its reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional products

location.town: Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom N., 43 years old, is a villager who lives in Trapeang Chrey village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice for a living.

For her farm Mrs. Mom N. is asking for a loan to buy an ox to assist her old ox with her farm chores. Mrs. Mom N. is also a Khmer cake seller in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Phally Ing, is a police officer and receives a small income to support his family. 

The couple has two children; one stays at home and helps with the mother's businesses while the other is a student in the local school. Her husband is in the photo too.

loans.use: To buy an ox.

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette is 25 years old, married with one child who is one year old.  Jeanette makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop and this is her 11th successful year in this business.  Jeanette's shop is open from 6 am until 7 pm every day.

After realizing that her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Jeanette is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Jeanette will hopefully earn more profits through the sale of foodstuffs as well as drinks, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting and saving for better financial stability.

loans.use: a variety of goods including foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Fidéle

texts.fr:
M. Fidèle est née à Gatsibo ex-province de Kibuye, le district actuel est Karongi, province de l’ouest, il a trente cinq ans, il est marié avec deux enfants, le premier a 5.5 ans et le deuxième a 3.5an. 
Concernant son activité, il a commencé par une boucherie qu’il a abandonnée pour le transport de taxi moto, avec expérience de 3 ans dans ce domaine d transport. Grâce aux épargnes faites du reste des dépenses des versements, il est devenu propriétaire de cette moto emprunté. Client d’ACB depuis juin 2008 il a déjà soldé un prêt. Il a sollicité un prêt pour le minerval de sa femme qui étudie en deuxième d’université. Dans l’avenir il pense passer l’examen pour l’obtention du permis de conduire catégorie D de taxi minibus,  puis contracter un prêt d’un montant important pour acheter un minibus qu’il conduirait lui-même , à la longue lui permettre d’abandonner les prêts et devient financièrement Independent.une fois les revenus augmentés, les conditions de vie de sa famille sont améliorés et il est qualifié parmi les riches du pays ainsi ses rêves sont réalises.
texts.en:
M. Fidèle was born in Gatsibo, the former province of Kibuye, which is now the district of Karongi, a western province. He is 35 years old, married with two children who are 5½ and 3½ years old. He began as a butcher, but later became a motorcycle taxi driver, which he has been doing for 3 years. Because he is thrifty and was able to save money, he became owner of the motorcycle which he had borrowed. He has been a client of ACB since June of 2008, and has already repaid a loan. He has requested this loan to pay the tuition of his wife, who is in her second year at university. In the future, he plans to sit for the test to obtain a Category D drivers license for a minibus taxi, then borrow enough to purchase a minibus which he would operate himself. Long term, this would enable him to increase his income and become financially independent. Theconditions of his life would be improved, and he would realize his dreams.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay tuition for his wife

loans.name: Ton

texts.en:
Mrs. Ton U. is 47 years old and is a villager who lives in Roluos village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vanna Rath, are farmers who own two hectares of land and their own agricultural machine to support their farming crop. Mrs. Ton U. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rice seed to support her farming crop. 

Aside from farming, Mr. Vanna Rath is able to earn a small income to support his family by renting out his agricultural machine to cultivate rice.
This couple has two children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory while another is a student in the local school. Her husband appears in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rice seed

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mrs. Suon T. is an older woman and the widowed mother of four children. One is now married and has started a new household, while the other three are single and living at home. She has a son who helps meet the financial needs of their family by driving a motorcycle taxi. To earn an income, Suon T. sells recycled materials. She buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods she deals in are mostly leftover electricity wires and plastic. Suon T. is looking for a loan to use as capital to buy more used goods in order to increase her profits. She also intends to use part of the loan to buy an old motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.use: To buy more recyclable materials

loans.name: Bakristo Kweterana Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
N. Sarah has been operating her hotel (restaurant) in Birunga, Ibanda, for the last eight years. Hard work, resilience and determination have been her winning factors over the course of these years.

For this married mother of eight, business success depends on hard work and she truly has lived up to it. In a week, she reckons she makes profits that amount to 90,000 shillings.

Sarah’s dream is to open up another branch in another part of western Uganda. This, she figures, will help her make more profits. She also wants to give her children the best education.

With proceeds from this loan, Sarah wants to take rejuvenation measures aimed at improving her hotel and she also wants to start on her plans to setup another branch. She wants to buy more furniture and cutlery for her hotel.

loans.use: To pay for refurbishment of her restaurant and also to buy more furniture and cutlery

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mrs. Bun T. started selling fish in her busy local market a number of years ago and has gained a lot of customers from this business. She is a single mother blessed with four teenage children; most of them help meet the family’s expenses by working in a restaurant. With this loan, Bun T. hopes to be able to buy fish in greater quantities for resale. With the extra profits, she hopes to improve her family's standard of traveling by buying an old motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy fish in greater quantities for resale

loans.name: Lucifa

texts.en:
Lucifa C. is a 47-year-old married woman from the village of Lingating Baungon Bukidnon. She and her husband have 5 school-age children. To earn a living, Lucifa owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, where her primary source of income is derived from selling both food and everyday products in her local community. Lucifa has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2007, Lucifa joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Recently, Lucifa successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 18,000 PHP from HSPFI. This prior loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lucifa is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 21,000 PHP ($475), which will again be used to purchase additional products. Notably, this loan would be the seventh loan taken out by Lucifa from HSPFI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and it reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional products

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan V. 41 years old and is a villager who lives in Chambak Tuem village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.50 hectares to cultivate rice, vegetables, and fruit for a living. Mrs. Chan V. has decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox to add her old one to support her farming crops. Her husband, Mr. Kay Sao, is a construction worker and receives a small income to support his family. This couple has a child, who is a student in the local school. The couple appears in the photo together.

loans.use: To buy an ox

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a married woman with four children. Her first-born has completed schooling, while the others still attend school. Janet has been operating a welding shop for the last 21 years, and her husband helps run the business. Their family rents a house with electricity but no piped water. She says that food and electricity are her highest monthly expenses.

Janet is now seeking a loan in the amount of 40,000 KES ($500) to purchase a metal brake, a metal bender, a magnetic clamp, and a metal file. She sells her work product out of her shop, to both neighbors and passersby.

She explains that her business is affected by the seasons, and that she is especially challenged during the months of January through March. She decided to work with Yehu because of its sustainable financial services offered to small-scale entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing certain tools (e.g., a metal brake)

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile is 42 years old and is married with two children who are 4 and 8 years old.

Cecile owns a small shop where she sells a variety of goods which include cooking oil and foodstuffs. She has been in this business for a long time. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Cecile is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and this loan will allow her to purchase a large quantity of foodstuffs for sale. With the sale of these foodstuffs, as they are highly demanded by a large number of her customers, she will hopefully earn more profits. This, in turn, will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and enable her to continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: To buy variety of goods to sell including foodstuffs, etc.

loans.name: Chenda

texts.en: Mrs. Chenda S., 28, lives in Srae Kruo village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mrs. Chenda S. decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox to add to her old one to support her farming. Her husband, Mr. Sarorn Heng, is a motorcycle taxi driver who is able to add a small income to support his family. This couple has three children; two are attending the local school, the third is one year old. Mrs. Chenda S. and her husband appear in the photo together.

loans.use: To buy an ox

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita V. is from the village of Tuburan in Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old and married with 5 adult children. To make a living, Teresita buys and sells bananas in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Morb

texts.en: Mrs. Morb L. currently weaves bamboo baskets for sale. She sells her finished product to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes over 100 sets of baskets before selling out. She also orders baskets from other villagers and sells them to make additional income. Her husband helps her buy the raw materials and weave baskets. Recently, Morb L. has run out of essential materials from her stock and hopes to acquire other raw materials to continue making baskets. She depends on using her Kiva loan as an advance. Morb L. is a 26-year-old married woman blessed with a school-aged child.

loans.use: To acquire other raw materials to continue making baskets

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie P. is from the village of West Poblacion in Kalilangan Bukidnon. She is 53 years old and married. To make a living, Elsie sells floor wax and has been doing so for over 3 years, earning about 8,000 PHP a month.  In 2009, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to  purchase additional inventory and working capital. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elsie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok N. 35 years old and lives in Roluos Village, Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Chhaom Nheb, are farmers who own three hectares of land to cultivate rice. In order to support this farming, Mrs. Sok N. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticides. Aside from farming, Mr. Chhaom is also a plowing machine driver, and he is able to earn a small income from his plowing machine to help support his family's living expenses. Mrs. Sok and Mr. Chhaom have three children, who all are students and also help out on the family farm. Mrs. Sok's husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticides to support a rice farm.

loans.name: Annalea

texts.en:
Annalea M. is from the village of Kolambog Lapasan in Cagayan de  Oro City. She is 31 years old and married with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Annalea is a butcher and meat seller for over 5 years now, and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.  In 2008, Annalea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annalea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to to purchase additional products to sell, and she now requests her 5th loan, for 14000 PHP, for the same purpose.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Kolambog, Lapasan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Orienta

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita C. is from the village of West Poblacion in Kalilangan Bukidnon. She is a 54-year-old widow with 9 children. Three of the children are still in school. Lucita has run a sari-sari (variety) retail shop for 6 years where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste. Lucita earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lucita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Lucita is requesting her 2nd loan, for 7,000 PHP, to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
